top_categories.workout_context: Race-pace efforts that mimic Sea Otter Fuego XL's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before April.
Sea Otter Fuego XL's mixed terrain forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 70 miles.
7,800ft of climbing means repeated surges above threshold. VO2max work is how you survive the fifth climb, not just the first.
111ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
At Sea Otter Fuego XL, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Sea Otter Fuego XL, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
Short, max efforts are unavoidable. Punchy climbs, gap closures, attacks on mixed terrain. If you haven't trained them, you'll crack.
7,800ft of climbing on grades that change every minute. You need to switch from seated to standing without losing rhythm.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Sea Otter Fuego XL. Train it until it feels boring.
70 miles on mixed terrain burns energy faster than the distance suggests. Train the fade resistance now.
Low-cadence force work for 7,800ft of climbing. The slow, grinding ascents where you can't spin—you push.
Endurance with intensity spikes baked in. Exactly what 7,800ft of climbing on mixed terrain does to your power file on race day.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 40–60g carbs/hour for Sea Otter Fuego XL’s 70 miles. Front-load calories in the first half. One bottle per hour minimum, more in heat.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at Sea Otter Fuego XL requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on mixed terrain to build confidence.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Race Simulation, Gravel Specific, and VO2max to prepare you for 70 miles of mixed terrain in Monterey, California.
